item.title: Sinosphere Blog: Fresh Doubt Over China’s Pledge to Amend Transplant Policy
item.description: Some disagree, saying that there has been a surge in voluntary donations as China announced it would end organ harvesting from death-row prisoners.
item.dc:creator: DIDI KIRSTEN TATLOW
item.media:description: Doctors performing surgery on a patient at a hospital in Tianjin. China is trying to change its organ transplant system to bring it more in line with international standards.

item.title: Sinosphere: Q. and A.: Sha Yexin on ‘The Conscience of Hu Yaobang’
item.description: In an interview, Mr. Sha discussed his encounters with the Communist Party chief and political reformer Hu Yaobang, the support he received from Mr. Hu’s son and whether the play will ever be staged in China.
item.dc:creator: VANESSA PIAO
item.media:credit: Xinhua, via Kyodo News, via Associated Press
item.media:description: The Chinese leader Deng Xiaoping, left, and Hu Yaobang, the Communist Party chief, saluting as they reviewed a military parade in 1981.

item.title: North Korea Seeks Talks With South
item.description: South Korea in recent weeks has repeatedly proposed to start agreed-upon government talks, but the North had not responded until Friday.
item.dc:creator: CHOE SANG-HUN

item.title: Imran Khan Sees His Vindication in a Calmer Pakistan
item.description: The cricket star turned politician’s populist style has played well in a country where anti-Americanism has always been a big vote-getter.
item.dc:creator: ROD NORDLAND
item.media:description: Imran Khan, the Pakistani opposition politician, during a protest in Islamabad last year.

item.title: Imran Khan Sees His Vindication in a Calmer Pakistan
item.description: The cricket star turned politician’s populist style has played well in a country where anti-Americanism has always been a big vote-getter.
item.dc:creator: ROD NORDLAND
item.media:description: Imran Khan, the Pakistani opposition politician, during a protest in Islamabad last year.

item.title: World Briefing: Yemen: 3 Detained Americans Are Allowed to Leave
item.description: A Yemeni security official said the men had been detained by the rebels and were flown out of Sana.
item.dc:creator: REUTERS

item.title: World Briefing: Britain: Libyan Tied to a Killing in 1984 Is Arrested
item.description: A Libyan man in his 50s was arrested Thursday on suspicion of conspiracy to murder the officer, Yvonne Fletcher.
item.dc:creator: THE ASSOCIATED PRESS

item.title: World Briefing: Northern Ireland: Top Political Figure Will Retire
item.description: Peter Robinson, 66, the first minister of Northern Ireland’s power-sharing government, said that he would retire from politics.
item.dc:creator: THE ASSOCIATED PRESS

item.title: World Briefing: Human Rights Committee Condemns North Korea
item.description: In a statement, North Korea criticized the resolution and claimed that the United States “and other hostile forces” were behind it.
item.category: Human Rights and Human Rights Violations
War Crimes, Genocide and Crimes Against Humanity
item.dc:creator: THE ASSOCIATED PRESS

item.title: Migrants’ Attempts to Enter U.S. via Mexico Stoke Fears About Jihadists
item.description: Federal officials said the migrants — from Syria, Pakistan and Afghanistan — appeared to have no radical intentions, but the episodes added to concerns after the Paris attacks.
item.category: Middle East and Africa Migrant Crisis
item.dc:creator: RICHARD PÉREZ-PEÑA

item.title: File Says N.S.A. Found Way to Replace Email Program
item.description: The spying agency found that it could collect Americans’ email data through other countries with less government oversight.
item.dc:creator: CHARLIE SAVAGE
item.media:description: The National Security Agency headquarters at Fort Meade, Maryland in 2010.

item.title: Paris Attacks Suspect Killed in Shootout Had Plotted Terror for 11 Months
item.description: Abdelhamid Abaaoud is believed to have organized a string of attacks that made him the most talked-about — and, in jihadist circles, feted — terrorist since Osama bin Laden.
item.dc:creator: ANDREW HIGGINS and KIMIKO DE FREYTAS-TAMURA
item.media:description: A soldier at Notre Dame cathedral in Paris on Thursday as part of heightened security after at least 129 were killed in Friday's terrorist attacks.

item.title: After 30 Years in Prison, Jonathan Pollard to be Freed — but Not to Israel
item.description: The American convicted of spying for Israel will be released on parole on Friday, but the Obama administration has no plans to let him move to Israel.
item.dc:creator: PETER BAKER
item.media:description: Jonathan J. Pollard in 1998. He was convicted of spying for Israel but received parole on a life sentence and will be released Friday.

item.title: Records Show Email Analysis Continued After N.S.A. Program Ended
item.description: The spying agency found that it could collect Americans’ email data through other countries with less government oversight.
item.dc:creator: CHARLIE SAVAGE
item.media:description: The National Security Agency headquarters at Fort Meade, Maryland in 2010.

item.title: Official Plane for Cameron Has Britons Unimpressed
item.description: The prime minister says having an official aircraft for government business is a security and money-saving measure, but others see an attempt to keep up appearances with other world leaders.
item.dc:creator: STEPHEN CASTLE

item.title: Israeli Officer Sentenced to Community Service in Beating of Palestinian-American
item.description: The border police officer who was filmed beating Tariq Abu Khdeir on the edges of a riot in East Jerusalem in July 2014 was also given a suspended prison term of four months.
item.dc:creator: ISABEL KERSHNER
item.media:description: Tariq Abu Khdeir, a Palestinian-American teenager who was beaten up by an Israeli border police officer in 2014. The officer was sentenced on Wednesday to 45 days of community service and to a suspended prison term of four months.

item.title: As France and Belgium Strengthen Security, a Classic Debate Arises
item.description: The two nations are each acting to toughen emergency powers in the wake of the Paris attacks, but some wonder if the cost to personal liberty is too great.
item.dc:creator: STEVEN ERLANGER and KIMIKO DE FREYTAS-TAMURA
item.media:description: Prime Minister Charles Michel of Belgium asked Parliament on Thursday to approve strict new security measures.

item.title: Obama Calls on Beijing to Stop Construction in South China Sea
item.description: In the Philippines for an Asia-Pacific Economic Cooperation summit, President Obama urged China to halt military activities on the disputed islands.
item.category: Far East, South and Southeast Asia and Pacific Areas
item.dc:creator: MICHAEL D. SHEAR
item.media:description: President Obama addressed the Asia-Pacific Economic Cooperation summit meeting in Manila, where he discussed China, trade and climate change.

item.title: Paris Victim Nohemi Gonzalez Was Pursuing Her Dreams in Design
item.description: Nohemi Gonzalez, a student from California and the only American known to have died in the attacks, was representative of the young, ambitious people who flock to the French capital.
item.dc:creator: DAN BILEFSKY
item.media:description: More than 2,000 people attended a vigil Sunday in Long Beach, Calif., for Nohemi Gonzalez, an American who died in Paris.

item.title: Civil War Legacy Continues to Divide Spain’s Politics and Its Streets
item.description: The street names and other symbols of the Franco regime across the country is a measure of how Franco’s legacy remains embedded in the political and physical landscape.
item.dc:creator: RAPHAEL MINDER
item.media:credit: Carlos Lujan for The New York Times
item.media:description: An air raid shelter at Lluis Vives High School in Valencia, Spain. A local civic association wants to turn one of the former air raid shelters into a civil war museum.
